This game has a niche target audience so I'll do my best to outline it below. If i have to give a rating I would give it an 8/10 and reccomend getting it on sale. I'm very aware that while I enjoy these games reccomending them is a bit dodgy as alot of people simply will not like what this game is. It does what it tries to do but that wont appeal to ALOT of people.



REASONS NOT TO BUY THIS GAME:
This game is not mechanically deep, characters roles are pretty simple to figure, beyond buffs debuffs and manipulating the turn system theres not alot to learn, the last one is a nice touch but still not a good game for someone who wants to think hard about their strategy.

Story is pretty poor in general (though not even close to as bad as rebirth 2 imo) and it has alot of repetition in monsters, dungeons etc.

The game is rated 12+ and that age level seems appropriate so if you're looking for adult images, look elsewhere. Fanservice is tame and sporadic.

It has quite alot of post game content through the free dlcs but unfortunately there is pretty much no way to progress to the last 4 areas or higher level fights in a  natural way. To do these you simply turn on the in-game power level hax" and grind levels for an hour or two. This means that to keep things fun post game you have to carefully balance your levels or else you will be annihilated/untouchable.

The difficulty is a bit low for alot of the games until you reach the ultra late-game at which point it reaches stupid levels and the only way to balance is essentially to be really careful about how you break the game (see above point)

The 4th wall gets SMASHED repeatedly here. All the games broke the 4th wall but this one just completely ignores to the point where even I got annoyed in later chapters and I'm normally immune to it.

REASONS TO BUY THIS GAME:
The games characters are the main draw. Its a mix of a visual novel with a turn based rpg and the characters keep the visual novel element highly entertaining for the most part. Having all the dlc characters active can make it a bit too much dialogue wise so I reccomend not using them for a first playthrough if you intend to do more than 1. reviewText:
Third time's the charm (?)
Fan's rejoice - the third game of Neptunia is here! Other gamers take a peak - another anime-style JRPG is here!
But is it a plain copy of the previous two games, or maybe it had some major improvements that makes it the best (Neptunia) game so far?

Story

Re;birth 3 once again places the player in the Gamindustri world, ruled by Goddesses[ideafintl.com]. Each rule a nation that represent a console company (Lastation -> Playstation, Leanbox -> Xbox, and so on) All seem peaceful after  the events of Re;birth 2, but our lazy and goofy main character just had to get herself in trouble again, didn't she?

The story is of the same pace as the previous games - it doesn't take itself too seriously, with it's long-winded boobie talk just before a serious boss battle, obscure gaming references at every single corner and blunt 4th wall breakings (The main character lives just to break it). But even so, Re;birth 3 probably tells  the longest and most decent story out of the 3 so far, which I personally enjoyed greatly. But do take note, that if it's a story-driven RPG you're looking for, you might need to rethink if this is what you're after.

Gameplay

The game's battle system remains mostly unchanged. It's still the typical turn based JRPG battle with the exception of being able to move the characters around for flanking and accurate special skill attacks (trust me it's much more simple than it sounds). The only change is the merge of SP bar and EXE drive bar, which is a healthy change. Before, you could just spam SP attacks and then finish it with very powerful EXE attacks. Now, you have to use SP for both specials and EXE attacks, so you have to play more smart.

The dungeon exploring remains mostly unchanged besides another very good change: the hidden treasure is no longer an invisible item in the dungeon that you had to spam a button to radar-search for it, it's now a mostly transparent Mario-type block that casts a shadow that the player can bump his head into for extra loot.

The levelling system finally feels balanced, the game doesn't suddenly throw in undefeatable mobs to get killed by, and you don't get too powerful too quickly (unless you use certain Plans...)

The Chirper also returns which is a direct replacement to talking to NPCs in other RPG games. It basically has almost zero use besides getting references, funny thoughts and similiar things. Though for some players it might be something to look forward to during each chapter start.

And the fun auto-exploring Stella's dungeon minigame returns again. This time, with more stuff to do. And with faster exploring too, which is a plus too. And this minigame also solves the problem of farming for materials as you can get a lot of them from the minigame too, while doing something else. Like reading the plot.

Speaking of plot, you will be met by a lot of it. A lot of text that is. Sometimes it really pulls the player out of the action just to read dozens of lines of text. While story is important, from time to time you may feel as the actual gameplay VS story reading" balance is off. Luckily you can still choose to skip the text relatively fast

So i am a huge Hyperdimension Neptunia fan and i have waited for PC release of Re;Birth 3 since it was announced on PS. I expected a lot from this game and i  am not dissapointed with any part of it .

The story is gorgeous. There is no way I can explain it. I really liked Re;Birth 1's story, felt average with Re;Birth 2's one, but I never felt bored with the storyline of Re;Birth 3. I was pleasantly surprised with the length of the story itself. In previous games it was up to 6-7 chapters. In V Generation there are  10 chapters . Lets have a look at the cons first, because, in all honesty, I did not find a lot of them:

Cons:-Game happens to have an fps drop when there is around 5-6 CPU models on screen, however if one of them disappears from your sight (for instance, by rotating your camera), framerate goes back to normal. It happened about 2 times in my gameplay.
-Some of the difficulty mechanics still hover around how many of your party members can get one shotted at the same time.

I really can't think about anything else. That's it. Really. I have not experienced anything else besides that. The quality increase between both first Re;Birth's and Re;Birth 3 is HUGE.

Noticeable pros in comparision with previous games:+Amazingly good plot
+Free DLC characters with fully voiced events
+NewGame+ content got expanded a lot and the game itself has a lot more content
+Extra combo slots + challenges which increase statistics of characters
+You can (finally!) rewatch previous events
+You can (finally!) preview items before buying them
+If character in the first row dies, you can switch her to her back buddy, and this actually is a huge game changer for end game
+The game does not force you to play all over again in order to get one item if you missed one dungeon at one exact chapter

Summary:This game is more than i have asked for. I have spent almost everyday playing it in order to relax and i loved every chapter, every dungeon and every quest i have completed. At the moment i have finished my first playthrough of the game which took around 52 hours. I really recommend the game to everyone and if you liked any of previous Neptunias you will fall in love with this one for sure.

This is how Hyperdimension Neptunia should've looked like from the beggining. Now, if you wonder if you should buy it, considering you are at that part of the review already, you most probably should.

10/10 My favourite game.

reviewText:
Synopsis:
Anime clichés, a story with plenty of humour related to the gaming industry, fourth wall breaking, grinding for crafting unlocks, cuteness, boobs and panties. Sound interesting? If yes, you'll probably LOVE this game. If not, you'd better stay waaaay over there! No, a few more steps backwards ... there!

Bigger and better, Rebirth 3 takes the series back where it belongs.


Pros:
* Very funny (unlike Rebirth 2)
* UI and mechanics improvements over previous titles
* Bigger
* Best story in the series (so far)
* Friendly to people new to the series

Cons:
* Easy
* Lack of new moves
* Some 3d cutscenes still as low-res as in the previous ones


To me, Rebirth 2 felt lackluster after the first game. The story wasn't as funny or as long, and dialogue dragged on with neverending pointless Chirper messages. Rebirth 3 feels like it goes back to what Rebirth 1 was: hilariously funny and full of protagonist wackiness and fourth wall breaking. The story continues after Rebirth 2. It feels more developed, and thanks to its nature and Nepgear's helpfulness it's easily understood by new people to the series. All old characters in the series return as playable characters although all of them don't participate in the main story. There are also some great new additions to the cast.

There are several mechanics improvements which make me happy. EX and SP point systems have been merged which makes skill management a bit more interesting. UI in the menus have improved. Stella's Dungeon now has a friendly drop list for dungeons and monsters. The map is bigger, with multiple layers and screens, providing space for more dungeons. No more search spam for hidden treasures; they have a new mechanic and are spotted visually. Visuals are also slightly better. The gallery is big, there are plans for changing BGMs and old scenes can be reviewed.

Unfortunately at the point where I'm at, the game feels a bit too easy. When I played Rebirth 1 I didn't feel bad about turning on Easier Enemies. Now I feel like I want to turn on Harder Enemies instead. The combat doesn't offer as much to old players as it could. The old characters all seem to use their familiar moves. The graphics in some 3d cutscenes are blurry and low-res, which can probably be blamed on the PS VITA original.

I'm thoroughly enjoying this one! Jury is still out, but possibly the best in the series. Thumbs up!

One of the best in the series in terms of story, some classic and touching 4th wall moments.   The Story continues off where MK2/Re;Birth 2 left off with Neptune being sucked into the UltraDimension and meets Plutia, the extreme Sadist CPU in the 16Bit Era.

The Good;

The main story is perhaps the best out of the series, its very well told and the voice actors do a great job as usual in bringing our favorite nepneps back.   Also Re;Birth 3 improves on several features such as an improved treasure hunting system so no longer spamming 'scan' in order to find those treasure, or reloading the same dungeon over and over to find rare or important items.

Also, I think its a positive change but others may disagree, they significantly changed how the SP system works, so now everything from healing spells, to the typical EX attacks use SP instead of previous games where special attacks/healing used mana and the EX had a seperate meter, its all combined now so some battles require a bit more strategy instead of just spamming the same attacks over and over.

Another good point is the awakening system, which gives a large stat boost to non-CPU characters, along the same lines as a HDD transform.

The Bad;

Now for the bad aspects,  unfortunately whilst the previous games mostly had limited bad points.  Victory//Re;Birth 3 does have several points which are quite negative and should be talked about, I will list these and explain them.

Ultra Extreme GrindFest (Worst in the Industry)

The developers incorporated new challenges into the game, by repeating the same process or achieving certain milestones, however they completely and honestly - went way over the top in terms of requirements for some of these,  such as jumping 10,000+ times... to unlock bonuses, I am not even kidding or lying how obnoxious some of these challenges can get,  luckily - no trophies are attached to them so for the most part, it unlocks stats/extra items or skills but still, it is way over the top considering these challenges are for each and every character in the game.

Another bad point is that the clothing has been priced far too high,  much much higher than the previous games so that all the unlockables and cute clothing are more or less a complete waste of time because by the time you've beaten the game, you'll still not be able to afford any of the clothing or accessories.  In fact,  getting money this time around is much harder than previous games.  In future games, I would like to see the clothing prices drastically reduced so that at least during the first cycle the player can at least purchase some clothing without skipping on upgraded gear.

Another minor point is a few boss fights, especially end of game have ultra cheap moves which can insta-kill and even immediately game over if your unlucky or not sufficiently levelled high enough to wipe her out in one turn.

reviewText:
As I accomplished every achievement, and, being a big fan of this game at the same time, I think that I already have enough understanding of the game as a basis to write a review, let's weigh up the pros and cons first:

Pros+ Funny and long storyline, 3 endings for players to choose, a walkthrough would take about 25-40 hours, depending on your choice to enjoy the story and gameplay.
+ Extremely cute characters makes players immerse rapidly into the game.
+ A wide range of varieties of weapons, items and crafts (plans) are provided.
+ Almost impossible to get stuck (because of difficulty) in the game as you can always gain reasonable amount of XP (a.k.a Experience Points) from enemies that have similar strength as you.
+ Pretty soundtracks can be found here.
+ Well-designed CGs.

Cons- Without achievement guides, it is too easy to miss important items that are necessary for further accomplishments in the game.  This problem was even more serious in earlier Neptunia games. It is recommended to read the guide carefully before starting the game if you want to get as many achievements as possible. Not so much of a big deal as a disadvantage, but still, better to be aware of missable events ^^.

As I mentioned, I’m a sincere fan of this series, so I’ll try to cover as many general aspects as I can possibly think of:

This game, which can be called HDN re birth 3 (on PC) or Victory (on PS3) for short, is a tactical role-playing game in which players take control of 4 characters both in the front line and the rear line (meaning 8 in total). This makes this latest product different in a more catchy way, probably easier to get the gist of the gameplay compared to the 2 earlier Neptunia games; for new players of HDN, I suggest you to play this first (like me), because this one gives less penalty compared to the 2 earlier ones. When a character dies, for example, in HDN Victory, the system still allow switches between the K.Oed character and the rear character, while in others you need to revive the dead before doing so, also, you have all the characters from the earlier games to use, and so on…….. but don't worry, the story in this game is settled completely differently from the earlier ones, only the same characters remains
.
However, sometimes you will still face challenges, in this case, there are two ways:
Develop a strategy or to train characters by fighting monsters from time to time. You can slay bosses which are difficult to beat at the first encounter more easily with the 2nd solution, but in my case for example, I always try to beat the boss with strategies in spite of being difficult, which wine and dines my own tactical strategy ^^, and well, sometimes this takes time -.- .

About the characters, well, let's say that you will never have enough with them, their cuteness is really, unbeatable (even I cannot resist >^<), in my opinion, this is a special and important feature for this series, every character is different, which is why the use of strategy becomes interesting here excluding the OPed histoire.

Speaking of items, weapons and crafts, we have an abundant amount of which in this game, this keeps leveling up the character’s ability as players upgrade their equipments while training. Crafts, which are called plans in this game, play an extremely important role in this game, some plans gives you extremely powerful weapons while others provide very useful items, many maps even require the corresponding plan to be unlocked, therefore, as far as I’m concerned, it is important to sometimes pause from advancing the storyline in order to get some plans done, this makes the gameplay a lot easier. There are different ways to get a plan done, some requires you to gather items from enemy drops, others needs you to gather ingredients in the field of a dungeon...... et cetera. Don't worry about getting bored, even exploring them can be fun ^^.

Soundtracks and CGs in this game are also well done. Idea Factory, together with Compile Heart, created its own style of character’s painting design which is genuinely unique, you can’t find anime artworks with similar ingenuity of manga creation elsewhere. Soundtracks are generally a good background support to the gameplay, although I can’t think of anything extraordinary, these soundtracks are special for me personally in terms of melody, hopefully you will enjoy them as well ^^.

About potential bugs, I don't think that I encountered more 5 bugs after 82 hours of gameplay, so for me, the gameplay is pretty solid. I'm sorry for players who often experiences crashes in game, I am not really helpful here...

Thank you for reading this review, I hope that this did give you a general idea on the system of the game as well as the main features. However, I have to say that even if it did, it remains only a vague introduction, there are tons and tons of things which only you can discover in this game, no descriptions can really work for HDN series. The only way to learn and have a deep understanding of it is to give it a try ^^.

reviewText:
So I've been playing this for a while and decided to do a detailed review for this game. (Since I can't make a funny one, hehe)

I played Re;birth1 and Re;birth2, simply put Re;birth3 is by far the best one in terms of everything. Unlike Re;birth2 that almost feels like the exact same Re;birth1 but played with other characters (the CPU Candidates), Re;birth3 has quite different features than the other two such as a slightly different battle system, different dungeon hidden treasure, different GUI, different World Map, and etc.

Though it is better than the previous games, Re;birth3 is back to having that same game design flaw with Re;birth1 that is having less party slot from the total of main characters. Re;birth1 mistake is that you only have 3 character slots while having 4 CPU goddesses, meaning you have to leave out 1 unfortunate CPU goddess in your party. Re;birth2 fixed this with having 4 slots for 4 CPU Candidates. But Re;birth3, while you now have 4 slots, the number of main CPU goddess is now 5 (or 6 if you want to count in Peashy). Yes, this isn't gameplay wise, but having to leave out one main character is painful.

Another problem that I have with the game, though not fatal but still bugs me, is how the optional events works for DLC characters, I won't spoil the content of the event and which one, but just expect a chronological order failure with it. In other words, the DLC events is not in sync with the main storyline.

Re;birth3 is back with CPUs as main protagonists, but with Noire, Blanc, and Vert have a slightly different personality as this game takes place in a different dimension from the previous game (while still being a direct sequel of Re;birth2). So have fun with Neptune being Neptune, Noire's arrogant tsundere, Blanc's raging attitude, and the now keep bragging about her chest, Vert. To make things better, Re;birth3 is introducing a new main character named Plutia, which personally I find it the best one from the five, play the game if you want to know why.

I haven't finish the whole game, but it seems the game is no longer shares-based, which might be nice to some of you that gets really really bored doing quests to control shares to aim for a specific ending like Re;birth2. Interestingly, Neptune comments about this in the game.

The game has a new optional feature called Challenges that basically an in-game achievements that grants additional bonuses or a Plan on completing it, for instance, jump 100 times and you get a permanent stat bonus. Though, it's too bad that the challenges are not global but attached to a single character, so you have a same bunch of the achievements that progress individually for each of the characters in the game.

Plans is more neat now, as you no longer have that annoyingly item change and add enemies plans from ciphers each time a new dungeon pop up. And the dungeon change is simplified for the greater good as it is basically only change the boss monster in the dungeon, making you easier to remember where to get material items since the regular monsters stays the same.

Stella Dungeon mini game from Re;birth2 is back although slightly different than the previous one. But worry not as the changes is for the better, you can access Stella's Dungeon in the menu now which is very very nice, and I think it is generally takes a much less time than Re;birth2 one, especially if you buy the DLC that made the floor search only takes 1 second to complete which make 100 floors Area only takes 1 minute and 40 seconds to complete.

Conclusion is that Re;birth3 is the best Neptunia Re;birth series ever made. I'll happily recommend this game to someone, though it is hard to recommend this without recommend them the previous games, especially Re;birth2 since the game is often referencing the events of Re;birth2 although not really a big deal to the game's storyline.

O yeah, I forgot to mention that this game is more HD than the previous games.

reviewText:
Beyond the horizons of the ever increasingly small place we live in lies the world of Gensokyo and Gamindustri, home to many an amazing sight most people here can never lay their eyes on. In this land, which has nearly been demolished in the Console Wars before threatening the balance between its rulers where an empty headed girl finds herself teleported to another dimension and now has to deal with the surprises coming from this situation while trying to find a way back to her own.

Even before the game itself begins, its picture on the store page and the opening animation after launching it already suggests that this game is going to be amazing, with the graphics coming into view next that shows the places waiting to be explored as the events of RB3 slowly begin to unfold. In that, the world map is visibly nicer to look at, with parts of the continent made separate instances so each would be much more detailed which makes it easy to navigate and even enjoyable to look at. Its dungeon mode and the combat taking place there are also pretty well made with the bigger moves being really flashy and the more basic ones being less so, but still interesting. The only gripe there is some of the underground caves being so dark, it makes treasure hunting very difficult without plans to help with.
There's also the story mode view which brings back many of the familiar places but with a new look, presenting various beautifully made landscape with Easter-style corridors, skyscrapers in the distance and many others, all of which make for an unusual but entertaining set. The character designs are also looking great with bringing back the old look of gals which were better in the first game and keeping the rest, while the new ones might be even better in appearance.

It also has a pretty great soundtrack with familiar songs returning that reall set the atmosphere, mostly the ones played during bossfights or in dungeons when fighting a harder monster. These pieces of musical arts make otherwise not too challenging battles awesome moments and one can't help, but seek them out to listen to these even a few more times. There's also the possibility to change them if one wishes to by completing plans, though since there are only very few of these and some of them don't fit the place where they can be heard, they aren't necessarily bringing the desired effect. Voice acting is also excellent with great performance from most actors, but even then, Plutia's is still really annoying which is not that nice since those playing will get to hear her a lot.

Still, even though these elements offer an incredible experience by themselves, so does the gameplay in this release. Our beloved dungeons make a comeback from the first installment with much the same layout which is helpful since it's easy directions this way, but this also brings some interesting changes. One being that finding hidden items is no longer achieved by spamming the radar once we begin exploring, but rather all spots are visible only the special ones being invisible while casting a shadow on the ground, and by jumping in the right place reveals them some coins and sometimes other stuff, but thankfully there aren't any items there which one has to scour the whole place for by visiting every blocks on the map. It is also possible now to find the location of materials needed for anything in the Remake interface, which is very helpful since you don't have to find everything all over the place anymore, so excellent moves here.
There have been significant changes to combat as well in the way that the developers cut the EXE Drive gauge out since everybody just spammed them to obliterate everything that happens to be in the area, so now they are tied to the SP meter depleting the vast majority of it after a single discharge. While this does make fights a little more tactical, it also sorta backfires sadly, because changing to HDD forms alone drains a portion of it already, and using their strongest attack takes away the rest, forcing the party members to spam rush attacks refill it or use less effective SP moves which often still require a lot. As such, this design was not quite the most agreeable way to make combat more exciting unfortunately.
This becomes even more pronounced with the introducing of challenges which are not unlike the ones one could see in Fairy Fencer F. Problem is, said successor of the EXE Drive is only unlocked through a plan for each character separately a milestone is reached in one, so the player is practically forced to play only a few girls, or they won't be able to reap the benefits they need. Not only that, this quickly becomes increasingly tedious as the next step in these require to repeat the same action impossible amount of times no sane person would bother to waste time on especially the last one, so while it sounds great at first its implementation is anything but satisfactiory. Therefore, only a few are actually worth to get like the fifth atrike slot in a combo or the flashiest skills you can get from there.
On the other hand Stella's Dungeon also returns but this times much more nicely with the adjustments to its design, mainly in the interface that is much easier to use now but also with other features like the option to pick a scout and also useful abilities that greatly increase her survivalibility as ashe ascends the floors of the tower in front of her. it is also the only way to acquire many plans for the Remake system with ingredients for stuff as a side benefit, so it's highly recommended to be used with a related DLC reducing risks and time sinking a lot as well.

Surprisingly enough the translation quality has also become a lot better with miswording so badly that I would fire the idiot who rewrote and not actually translated the original script being much rarer now, and while the destruction of cultural aspects like Nepgear-chan butchered into Nep Jr. is still difficult to accept, it finally reached a point where it's on a more tolerable level. It's kind of eyebrow raising when someone who never studied Japanese language in a language course could translate lines better than a guy who gets paid for that. Seriously.
And while it's not such an important issue one might find it amusing in the storyline that having different time speed is impossible since the characters wouldn't be able to communicate then. It'd create a phenomenon not unlike in a Stargate episode where time went so slowly it cancelled out any kind of way to contact others from the outside. It is most definitely a plothole, but on the other hand, it was never mean to be accurate in terms of physics.
On the other hand, Plutia's simply the worst since her aything but likeable and borderline antagonistic behavior ruins many of the otherwise enjoyable scenes which clearly shows how she should be an enemy, not ally. This is a very big demerit since anybody who isn't into that kind of messed up character will find her less than agreeable, yet we're forced to watch the stunts she pulls out of her rear end, especially as the events progress.

While this game still has its share of inconsistencies and flaws however both inherently and through localization, after the massive trainwreck of the second installment in this series liked only by the mindless sheeple who outright ignored every single flaw it had no matter how glaring, it was a pleasant turn seeing how this release was made so much more enjoyable. Following the best traits of the previous ones while fine tuning the gameplay now makes for an even more amazing experience which doesn't happen often in sequels. The Victory in its title is therefore an amusing piece of humor, since it's indeed a win.

Having put nearly 100 hours in to this game, gotten the true ending and seen most of what it has to offer, I can say this is my favorite of the Rebirth series and can very much reccomend to fans of anime, moe, and JRPGs.

Gameplay is more or less the same as in Rebirth 1 and 2. The combat system isn't incredibly deep, but it works and is fun enough (though I still feel the Break chain of attacks is relatively useless). HDD attacks feel a bit more balanced and not nearly as broken as in Rebirth 1.

Story wise, though the Neptunia games have never had strong stories, but this one feels the best to me. It follows Nep as she is transported to another dimension, the world of the 1980's game industry, which is a novel idea and leads to fun geeky jokes about the era. The characters have always been what drives the Neptunia games, and this one brings back nearly every previous character in some form, which I adore.

I found the game relatively easy for most of the main story, but that post game content, dungeons, and Colliusum battles require strategy and will kick your ♥♥♥ if you aren't prepared, which I really like. It's an appreciated difficulty bump for more hardcore players.

If I had complaints, the biggest one is the continued recycling of dungeons and enviroments. There are only a handful of dungeon layouts, and new" dungeons are simply old ones with a new enemy coat. This was a problem in Rebirth 1 and 2 and it's a bit irritating it coninues here. The required amount of level grinding is also very grating.

But overall
date: Rebirth 3 is my favorite of the Rebirth games and I don't regret putting in the time. Had a lot of fun! Must play for fans of Nep Nep.\n\nLive Long and Nep Nep~"

reviewText:
Third installment of the neturnia game series released on steam, now it's hard not to openly compare it to the other two before it but so I won't really try, sorry. As far as game difficulty goes its in between the first and second one, the first Re:birth being the hardest and the second being the easiest.
The easiest point of this game is the shear number of characters you get though DLC (which appears be to DLC mostly if you have saves from the previous games rather then buying) outside of the DLC characters it has the smallest cast of playable characters being only the CPU's, (so take it as you want on the DLC characters being bad by making it easier or good to make up for the lack of characters).
Combat system is the same as the previous two with a few diffrences, first off collusium battles are easier now with the monsters being less OP, second off you are given the option of switching KO'd character with there back character, and third, the EX system of the game for combat has been drastly changed, rahter then a shared EX gadge that is shared by the party it is based on the individual characters SP, alsong with those changes SP regenerates a little per hit and all characters have there SP locked at 1000 (no increasing it this game). Along that some line of though I want to add this means you can't spam HDD all the time, your SP doesn't recover when you leave a dungeon, it only recovers from battle or items, but a small plusside (for the DLC characters at least) everyone has an HDD action, or rather none CPU's have Awakening, more or less a super sayain golden aura with boosted stats.
Music is still more or less the same with a few plans that can let you change the music (but only the default or a single alt.)
Another new addition (Which can be really annoying if your a completionist) is a challange system, basicly you do something a number of times and you unlock stuff (mostly small stat ups with the final level of the challanges being a large stat up, but also some plans), the ploblem here is that some of these are beyond annoying such as one challange where you have to run away from battle, the final level of the being run away from battle 3000 times (and again just one of several) and also it only applies to the active characters (meaning for the one were you have to walk around the map for so many meters you have to do with ALL the characters to competly complete it).
Story wise you'll see a lot of similarity between the anime version with some base setting from the second game (and somehow a lot of refrensing to the first). The story was good and had a lot of good build-up with a bit of acualy game history in it (you'll more or less see the game industries history be built up and refrenced a lot, specially with processors for the CPU you unlock frequently at the start of new chapters). Fans of the series most likly already know that Plutia is a main character so lots of great stuff to expect (Including a priceless scene between Iris Heart, IF, and Arfoir).
Overall tone of the game feels more like the first one with the more wacky and sillyness that you've come to love (or might come to love) from the series and managing to mix in nicely a somewhat serious tone channeling more of the same feel with the first Re:birth but with a lot more fourth wall breaking in this, to a point where even some of the villians do it.
Overall if your a fan of the neptunia series, or wanting to play a less intensive/serious RPG this is a good game to get and unlike the second Re:birth without any major game breaking DLC (except an experience booster plan but easy enough to ignore)

reviewText:
Re;Birth3 V Generation is basically a direct improvement over the previous entries in the series, and in many ways is even superior to the most recent mainline release, Victory 2. The quality-of-life improvements in R;B3 from previous entries are substantial, and the game itself, for those who haven't played Victory, is superb.

The Neptunia franchise, for those unfamiliar, features fairly standard JRPG gameplay, but the main attraction are the visual-novel-esque story and character interaction segments. In contrast to mk2/R;B2, Victory/RB;3 features a story that is far more about the characters than an overarching plot (though one is present). Most of the time you spend playing the game will probably be spent watching the very colorful cast interact with each other. The initial party (and main characters in this entry) of Neptune, Plutia, and Noire is an excellent combination of personalities that really sells the more slice-of-life atmosphere present in R;B3 compared to its predecessors. I think it really should be mentioned that Kana Hanazawa, who provides the voice for Plutia, is near her best in this game, demonstrating an absolutely masterful range and stellar performance.

Having played and enjoyed all of the main games in the franchise, I personally find Re;Birth 3 to be the most entertaining and fun entry in the series, narrowly beating out even V2. If you have played any of the other games in the series, I strongly encourage you to purchase this game, and if you have not yet played a Neptunia game but are interested in the series I think RB;3 is the best place to start.

reviewText:
Well the game the first 2 remakes were based on has finally hit steam. Did you play the first two and like them? Well this game is what they're based off of, well the original PS3 version (pre-remake) anyway. It's got some tweeks to it to be certain but it almost feels like an episodic game at this point.
Combat is fast and fluid, has some customization to it and is fun to do. The cutscenes are as basic as the previous ones, slightly animated portraits that talk at eachother infront of static backgrounds.

The music is funky, the character visuals and animations look great, backgrounds are like a budget PS2 era game (as usual). Gameplay is broken into long sessions of dialogue dumps, then you can hunt for more chatter on the overworld map, then there's the dungeons where ....I'm sure there's a review here that dives into this better than me, there's a lot you can do to dungeons to alter them with enemies and item drops.

There's not a lot to say on it since a lot of the visuals are reused, as is music, animations and the like. It's as dumb and fun as before, just with more polish. The human characters are given more balance by being able to power up like the CPUs, so you have a better selection of characters this time....and a lot of them to be sure. Every character you've ever seen in the series so far.

Seriouness aside, I enjoy the nerdy console/game jokes they sling around a bunch, getting more of them than I'd like to admit. The humor is dumb, silly and cliche at parts. Fanservice? Not so into that but it's there if you like it!

My complaint lies in the imbalance of the DLC characters, it's awful. Some are insanely OP because of gear, and others have sub par gear and you can't upgrade them through much of the story. Ex: Kid IF has really strong weapons that were great for 2 chapters, regular IF has crap weapons and even weapons bought later had her lacking behind any other character by a long shot. But then you get Histy or the like and they have vastly superior gear to anyone and everyone. At level 1 they'll best your level 30+ characters in damage.

Fun game, more of the same and hopefully now that they're done remaking they'll have more variety in the series.

IF is the best character still, just FYI, the main character really. I dunno why they keep calling it Neptune" when the only smart one of the bunch is kickin' ♥♥♥ and moving the party of GODS along."

reviewText:
Many of you are wondering if this game is worth playing if you've played Rebirth 1 and is it different. And I'm here to tell you...

Short version- YES!

Long version-
First off, the story focuses on just the CPUs. While the side characters can still be there, they're included as dlc when you download the game, so you can choose whether to have them in the game or not!

Second, there's changes to the gameplay. While the core gameplay exists (rush, power, and break attacks), it's a lot more different that 1&2. Now, instead of an exe drive, you know use the sp bar for exe related attacks. Meaning you can't spam the exe attacks like you use to, and you also have to plan how you use your other sp attacks. Meaning the game is a lot more strategic!

Third, grinding is a lot more fun now thanks to some additions. Each character can level up by doing certain tasks. For ex. Neptune finding 10 items as a lead character can level up her luck. And this goes for EVERY character, giving you a reason to swich who you leader is. (Oh, and btw, there's leader skills too!)

And even though there's much more, the last thing I'll say is that THIS ISN'T A BAD PORT! If you ran rebirth 1, you'll have no trouble running rebirth 3. :D

So what are you waiting for, get the game!

reviewText:
First thing I want to point out. This is indeed the best Neptunia game I have played so far compared to Re;Birth 1 and 2.

My reasons? It's because this game literally references back when Sega and Nintendo were fighting.
If you don't know ANY of this, you will NOT enjoy this. I repeat, if you seriously don't know about history between where Sega does what Nintendon't and when Playstation comes in to make both Sega and Nintendo's life hard, please don't say this game is bad because you simply don't understand what the creators tried to show here.

That was literally the purpose of this game. Though I'm only in chapter 3, I'm already laughing my butt off because of the references to these old consoles with their pathetic weaknesses. It also shows how old game companies used to live and die and if you did a lot of research, Neptunia references a LOT of game companies and of course other games.

If you have played the first 2, you'd love the fact that in the third installment, you don't have the SP gauge no more, in other words, no more worrying you'd run out of SP and instead, more beating up stuff. Sure it gets repetitive, but to complete the game, it's not that bad. Unless of course if you are like me who tries to 100% the game. I've 100% Neptunia 1 and 2 and trust me, it can get a little repetitive, but very worth it. I may change this review again after I finish the game, but I seriously enjoy this game too much already due to the references and better mechanics compared to the first and second. Take my advice if you are into retro games.

reviewText:
Overall an improvement. A lot of the good things about Fairy Fencer F are in this game. I do wish they didn't reuse so many dungeons. I will say that the new dungeons are a bit of fresh air, and absolutely gorgeous. However, the amount of reused dungeons is staggering. Well, they aren't reused as much as a bunch of dungeons were created / taken from Rebirth 3 / Neptunia V

They re-recorded the voices. A side-effect is that Neptune's Japanese voice has a higher pitch. Ugh. That took a while to get used to. Plutia is another paint-by-numbers character, but her interactions make up for a lot. Noire steals the spotlight though. I also like that IF and Compa aren't in the beginning of the game. I haven't gotten too far, yet

I don't like Plutia that much. She was pretty good for a while, but they took her over the top. There's also improvements on item finding. You can now press Y in the requirements list to tell you which dungeon, if you have it unlocked, has the item. I guess they realized that we'd Google it anyways

As a budget game, it's good. I wouldn't buy it at $30 though.

I also get some lags in the new dungeons. I have a Core i7 4790k and a Radeon 7870. Is it supposed to be doing this?

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 is a colorful and fun JRPG filled with lots of cuteness,weirdness and an assortment of many animu girls. The odd,yet very interesting thing is that the girls are all based or represent game consoles or game engines.

Pros:
+Very fun story and dialogue between the characters
+ Cute and likeable characters
+4th wall breaking- Adds a certain charm to the game and makes things funnier
+Battling- You will be doing a lot of battles in which you will be doing the same thing over and over again,but because of the pretty animations and cool Special abilities,it doesn't get boring
+Design of characters- All of the characters have some things,like ribbons,hairpins or clothing that clues and hints on the game console or engine they are representing
+Customization- Many accesories and clothing to dress your characters into
+Do a lot of stuff- There is a lot of grinding to be done and for the most part it is well done
+Story is easy to get into- Playing the previous Hyperdimension games is not necessary to understand the story,since it pretty light-hearthed
+Light yuri and ship-teasing

Cons:
-Technical Difficulties- Had to mess a lot with the properties and install some other stuff to get the game to function properly. Sometimes the game stilll crashes for me on one of the two PC's I played this game on.
-Too difficult to grind- I said that the grinding was well done,but there are some things that require an insane amount of work and time spent to be achieved. Getting all of the endings is one of those things. (to get them all you need to beat the game 3+ times!)
-Dungeon and enemy recycling- This is a very big game,which uses recycled maps and enemies to great amount. While I can tolerate the recycling of enemies,since a lot of RPG's and other games do that,I can't tolerate the recycling of the same map for 4+ times.
-Repetition of tropes- This is an anime-like game and expect to see a lot of stuff you saw a million times before (There is the topic of breast sizes,which the characters talk about quite a handful of times. It may be funny the first or second time,but after that you feel like you are watching you saw already and know the ending of it).
-Not enough yuri - Moar is required

Overall,this game is/was very fun to play and I will spend more time playing it. Hyperdimension is one of the best RPG's I played and will be a big favorite of mine. Looking forward to more Hyperdimension Neptunia games and I may play the other games aswell. Recommending this to everyone who likes RPG,anime stuff or just colorful and fun filled games.

So, a return to the Hyperdimension Series. Frankly, as far as i'm concerned, Compile Heart and Idea Factory (US)/Marvelous AQL (EU) can't pump out these games fast enough. Each is good in its own right.

Do note that if you're expecting a serious plot with high drama then this is not the game for you.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 returns to the universe first introduced by Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 2 and sees the characters of that universe once again battling the forces of piracy in abstract form. However, where Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 2 tackled this basic plot in a rather anvilicious manner, R3 is altogether a better game. This is largely because of the reinclusion of Neptune as the main character and the antics she brings to the table; the Hyperdimension Series has never been about the story itself, but about the interaction with the characters that the writers bring to the table, and their interactions with each other. As such, HDN: R3 improves upon the formula introduced by the first game in almost every way but one: combat.

Part of the fun, personally speaking, was being able in HDN: R1 to pull off insane attacks with little effort. R3 attempts to curb this abuse" by making EXE attacks both unlockable via achievements and require most--if not all--of a character's SP. reviewText:
Half JRPG, half Visual Novel; Neptune and our favorite characters of all shapes and sizes return for another game full of light humor, fanservice, fourth wall breaking and button mash-to-win. Compared to the previous titles, the battle system has been revamped, changing the SP/EXE drive system, introducing plans to extend combos, enabling up to four characters to fight simultaneously and more. Plus you no longer have to mash the Y key in dungeons while hearing the same sound over and over to find hidden goods. They're now in convenient boxes scattered across the world. Yay!

Story-wise, the game sticks to its roots. Everything is taken lightly, cuteness and the occasional fanservice is everywhere. Some jokes are taken a tad too far - the size of Blanc's chest to fourth wall breaking stacked onto fourth wall breaking. It's actually a rather refreshing Visual Novel, with a good portion of the story events voiced. Plus, the option to swap between the English and Japanese voices is a plus.

In terms of the combat and dungeoning, Re;birth3 does a better job at balance and dungeon progression, with a defined difficulty curve in the story dungeons and a large number of side dungeons in case one wishes to do some grinding. Yes, the dungeons are repetitive, often the same tileset with minor modifications, and most enemies (there are actually many different types) usually share the same sprites, but it isn't too big of a deal. The new combat system starts feeling a bit odd, considering SP and EXE are now one and the same, but eventually you get used to it and realize how ridiculous SP Boosters are. Unfortunately this makes Rush type skills far less valuable as SP Boosters now contribute directly to EXE Drive and Skills can be spammed less. The plus side is you don't have to grind EXE every single time a dungeon instance is entered or reset.

Like the other remakes, re;birth3 has a ton of DLC (which is actually included this time for free! sans the mega-convenient one) adding in a ton of humorous events and characters. Stella's dungeon is back from re;birth2 with far more valuable rewards to be gained. Mostly the same system, but some bonus items can be scored by having a scout detect a new area upon clearing a floor.

Overall, as a JRPG, the game is quite simplistic, and fairly grindy (even with Super EXP Up). Not really for everyone, especially those who aren't really a fan of the art/story/characters. As a Visual Novel, the game is incredibly entertaining, making events shy away from mashing a button hoping it ends to something worth savoring. Especially if it's voiced. If you're a fan of the Neptunia games, this is definitely worth it. If you don't mind grindy JRPGs and a bit of fanservice, this is definitely worth it. Eh. As long as you don't mind the art style, characters, JRPG elements and writing, this game is totally worth it.

Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 is a colorful and fun JRPG filled with lots of cuteness,weirdness and an assortment of many animu girls. The odd,yet very interesting thing is that the girls are all based or represent game consoles or game engines.

Pros:
+Very fun story and dialogue between the characters
+ Cute and likeable characters
+4th wall breaking- Adds a certain charm to the game and makes things funnier
+Battling- You will be doing a lot of battles in which you will be doing the same thing over and over again,but because of the pretty animations and cool Special abilities,it doesn't get boring
+Design of characters- All of the characters have some things,like ribbons,hairpins or clothing that clues and hints on the game console or engine they are representing
+Customization- Many accesories and clothing to dress your characters into
+Do a lot of stuff- There is a lot of grinding to be done and for the most part it is well done
+Story is easy to get into- Playing the previous Hyperdimension games is not necessary to understand the story,since it pretty light-hearthed
+Light yuri and ship-teasing

Cons:
-Technical Difficulties- Had to mess a lot with the properties and install some other stuff to get the game to function properly. Sometimes the game stilll crashes for me on one of the two PC's I played this game on.
-Too difficult to grind- I said that the grinding was well done,but there are some things that require an insane amount of work and time spent to be achieved. Getting all of the endings is one of those things. (to get them all you need to beat the game 3+ times!)
-Dungeon and enemy recycling- This is a very big game,which uses recycled maps and enemies to great amount. While I can tolerate the recycling of enemies,since a lot of RPG's and other games do that,I can't tolerate the recycling of the same map for 4+ times.
-Repetition of tropes- This is an anime-like game and expect to see a lot of stuff you saw a million times before (There is the topic of breast sizes,which the characters talk about quite a handful of times. It may be funny the first or second time,but after that you feel like you are watching you saw already and know the ending of it).
-Not enough yuri - Moar is required

Overall,this game is/was very fun to play and I will spend more time playing it. Hyperdimension is one of the best RPG's I played and will be a big favorite of mine. Looking forward to more Hyperdimension Neptunia games and I may play the other games aswell. Recommending this to everyone who likes RPG,anime stuff or just colorful and fun filled games.

reviewText:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 is a colorful and fun JRPG filled with lots of cuteness,weirdness and an assortment of many animu girls. The odd,yet very interesting thing is that the girls are all based or represent game consoles or game engines.

Pros:
+Very fun story and dialogue between the characters
+ Cute and likeable characters
+4th wall breaking- Adds a certain charm to the game and makes things funnier
+Battling- You will be doing a lot of battles in which you will be doing the same thing over and over again,but because of the pretty animations and cool Special abilities,it doesn't get boring
+Design of characters- All of the characters have some things,like ribbons,hairpins or clothing that clues and hints on the game console or engine they are representing
+Customization- Many accesories and clothing to dress your characters into
+Do a lot of stuff- There is a lot of grinding to be done and for the most part it is well done
+Story is easy to get into- Playing the previous Hyperdimension games is not necessary to understand the story,since it pretty light-hearthed
+Light yuri and ship-teasing

Cons:
-Technical Difficulties- Had to mess a lot with the properties and install some other stuff to get the game to function properly. Sometimes the game stilll crashes for me on one of the two PC's I played this game on.
-Too difficult to grind- I said that the grinding was well done,but there are some things that require an insane amount of work and time spent to be achieved. Getting all of the endings is one of those things. (to get them all you need to beat the game 3+ times!)
-Dungeon and enemy recycling- This is a very big game,which uses recycled maps and enemies to great amount. While I can tolerate the recycling of enemies,since a lot of RPG's and other games do that,I can't tolerate the recycling of the same map for 4+ times.
-Repetition of tropes- This is an anime-like game and expect to see a lot of stuff you saw a million times before (There is the topic of breast sizes,which the characters talk about quite a handful of times. It may be funny the first or second time,but after that you feel like you are watching you saw already and know the ending of it).
-Not enough yuri - Moar is required

Overall,this game is/was very fun to play and I will spend more time playing it. Hyperdimension is one of the best RPG's I played and will be a big favorite of mine. Looking forward to more Hyperdimension Neptunia games and I may play the other games aswell. Recommending this to everyone who likes RPG,anime stuff or just colorful and fun filled games.

reviewText:
Re;Birth 3 is all Re;Birth 2 is not.
If you're a Nepper, that's all you need to know to buy this game.

All the humor is back and all the actually fun characters are back, which makes this as good as Re;Birth 1, but bigger, longer, and with more fanservice (Tip: Buy the extra characters and extra content DLCs, they're really cheap and it's worth it, they all come with their own events per chapter, and you'll have a good laugh).

Character-wise, the Ultradimension CPUs are slightly different from their Hyperdimension counterparts, but I'm confident you'll enjoy the differences (for starters, UD Blanc actually has a personality, and the brief flashes of the love triangle with Plutia and Noire are pure gold), and Plutia is not only a most faithful embodiment of Sega's candid 8bit days (down to the consistent use of lilac and white color scheme), her CPU form is, well, an embodiment of Sega's abusive relationship with its customers on its last days; probably the best waifu-ification job of a gaming company of all the cast.

Gameplay-wise, it's fair I give you a heads-up: As you might have already noticed from Re;Birth 2 (if you had the misfortune of playing it), Neptunia has a habit of compulsive re-using: From dungeons to monsters to music tracks, every game asset from Re,Birth 1 is re-used time and time again. But then, the point of sale of Neptunia games lies with their charismatic characters and hilarious writing, so I didn't find myself bothered by the deja-vu and neither should you.

Speaking of Re;Birth 2, if you had the misfortune of playing it, you'll be glad Compile Heart took feedback to heart and castigated their prior game hilariously.

Warning 2: Just as with Re;Birth 2, the last chapter and true ending require you to do some stuff. Fortunately, Re;Birth 3 is way more forgiving than 2 and the conditions are harder to miss. Just read a guide here on the forums and you're golden.

My only complain: If this game aimed for the early days of the console war... where are all the old discarded consoles?? Where's SNK? Where's Nec? Where's Panasonic? Where are Phillips and Bandai? Where's Mattel? That was one HUGE wasted opportunity. WARNING: COMMENT ON THE GAME's LAST CHAPTER I'd have actually left Planeptune in ruins after Ryghts' bombardment and turned Nep into a wandering Wuxia goof to remain faithful to what happened in the console wars. If they actually went into the part of cell phones in our current Second Videogame Crash, they could have gone all the way while they were at it.

10/10, would Nep again (and probably will, New Game+ is an option). Can't wait for Hyperdevotion Noire and Action Unleashed to get to Steam.
